close_symbols: struct Page (pages[] element type: url, handler, handler_cls, mime)
explanation:
To decide whether any portion of create_response is statically unreachable we must know the definitions and semantics of all symbols that control its branches and loop termination. In particular:

- pages / struct Page: The while-loop and final call pages[i].handler depend on the pages array layout, the sentinel (pages[i].url == NULL) and whether handler can be NULL. Knowing pages[] contents and termination is essential to determine if the search loop or handler call can be skipped or is unreachable.
- struct Request: Fields pp, session and post_url are tested/used; their types and initialization rules affect whether branches (allocation path, POST-processing, session setup, use of post_url) can be taken or are impossible.
- post_iterator: Passed to MHD_create_post_processor as a callback; its presence/semantics can affect whether POST handling is intended/used (relevant to reachability of POST branch).
- get_session: Its return behavior (can it return NULL?) controls reachability of the error-return branch when request->session is NULL.
- MHD_create_post_processor / MHD_post_process / MHD_destroy_post_processor: These functions control multiple branches — creation failure (NULL), post-processing failure (return != MHD_YES), the case where upload_data_size != 0 causes an early return, and the cleanup path. Their possible return values and side effects are needed to judge whether those branches are reachable.
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static / METHOD_ERROR / MHD_queue_response / MHD_HTTP_NOT_ACCEPTABLE / MHD_destroy_response: The unsupported-method error path at the end is reachable only if method is not POST/GET/HEAD; the response creation/queue/destroy functions and METHOD_ERROR constant are needed to confirm that this path is a real runtime branch (not eliminated by macros or constants).
- MHD_HTTP_METHOD_POST / MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET / MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD: These define the strings compared with method. If any are aliased or defined such that comparisons always succeed/fail, branches become unreachable — so their definitions are required.
- MHD_YES / MHD_NO: Values used to test results (MHD_post_process return and create_response return). Knowing their definitions is necessary to reason about comparisons and unreachable return paths.
- strcmp: The code uses strcmp to choose branches; if strcmp is redefined or macro'd differently this affects reachability.
- calloc / strerror / errno: calloc can fail (NULL) causing the early error return; strerror/errno used in reporting but errno semantics help assess whether that error path can occur.
- time: Used to set session->start; while not affecting branching much, its presence can be needed to determine side effects that might render code required/used.
- strlen: Used when building the METHOD_ERROR response; its behavior and any macros affecting it could impact whether that final error-response creation code is reachable.

Providing these symbols (definitions and semantics) lets the analyzing agent determine whether any conditional or code block in create_response can never be executed (i.e. is unreachable) under the program's actual definitions and constants, as required to assess MISRA's "no unreachable code" rule.
